p: One of the most common symptoms of the acute phase of infection is an abrupt onset of fever, coincident with the viremia and polyarthralgia, reaching 40°C in some cases, resulting in chills and rigors ( Simon et al., 2011). Fever, in addition to lasting from many days to 2 weeks, are also typically biphasic in nature (with a period of remission of 1–6 days) ( Halstead et al., 1969; Thiberville et al., 2013), which means an early elevation in body temperature followed by a later one, caused by a dynamic balance between exogenous and endogenous pyrogens and prostaglandins.
